page.title: 09People and Housing
page.content: The area boasts housing dating from Medieval times.No less than 19 buildings have survived from the 14th and 15th centuries and a further 13 were built during the Tudor and Stuart periods.However the major proportion of housing development has been post-war and more particularly during the past 20 years.Modern housing estates proliferate, varying between exclusive developments offering individual architect designed homes built to a traditional style of brick under tile roofs, often in extensive grounds,to small semi-detached or terraced homes, factory built and assembled on site, with very small gardens. In 1981 the population stood at 22,395 and it is anticipated that there will be 24,090 people living in the town by 1986.
